title: Opening a Unix Shell at OSC
section: Open a Unix shell at the Ohio Supercomputer Center (OSC)
text:
Open a Unix shell at the Ohio Supercomputer Center (OSC)

If you haven’t already: create an OSC account by following the link in the email you received from OSC.
Go to https://ondemand.osc.edu and log in.
Once you are logged in, you should see a landing page similar to the one below:



Click on the Clusters dropdown menu in the top blue bar, and then on Pitzer Shell Access:





This should open a new browser tab that looks approximately like this:










Your screen will be slightly different from the screenshot above:




You should see even more “welcome messages” (which is everything except for the last line), and some of these are personalized, so they will differ for you.
The last line in the screenshot (jelmer@pitzer-login04 ~]$) is your shell “prompt”, which is personalized as well:

You will see your own username (not jelmer) before the @
You may be on a different “login node” so may e.g. see @pitzer-login03

title: Opening a Unix Shell at OSC
section: Copy the Software Carpentry data set
text:
Copy the Software Carpentry data set
If you opened a shell in order to do the Unix shell homework, then please also perform the following step:

Copy and paste the following code in your Unix shell, and then press Enter (this will create a folder (directory) called “Desktop” in your home directory, and will copy the Software Carpentry dataset into the new Desktop folder):

mkdir Desktop
cp -r /fs/scratch/PAS2250/cabana/homework/shell/shell-lesson-data Desktop/

After doing this, you should be able to skip everything on the Software Carpentry “Summary and Setup” page.








If you run into any problems, don’t hesitate to email Jelmer Poelstra.

title: R and Unix Shell Homework
text:
If you have very limited or no experience with R and/or the Unix shell1, please go through the following homework before you need these skills in the workshop on Wednesday.
If you do have some experience with R and the Unix shell, we would suggest that you at least take a look at the material below, to check that you are familiar with most or all of its contents.

title: R and Unix Shell Homework
text:
R
Please work your way through the Data Carpentry “XX” lesson…

title: R and Unix Shell Homework
text:
Unix Shell
Please work your way through the Software Carpentry “Shell Novice” lesson up until and including at least episode 3 (“Working With Files and Directories”).
You can optionally make your way through the remaining episodes, but that content will in part be taught in the workshop itself, and in part not be used at all.







Using Windows?



If your computer uses the Windows operating system, you will not have a Unix shell installed by default2. To go through the lesson above, you have two options:

Install a Unix shell
Follow the instructions in the Software Carpentry lesson that I linked to above (and here is a direct link to the installation instructions). If this fails for you, please use the next option instead.
Use a Unix shell at the Ohio Supercomputer Center (OSC)
Follow these instructions elsewhere on this website.

title: R and Unix Shell Homework
text:
Footnotes


The Unix shell is also known as the “terminal” or “command line”.↩︎
If you have a Mac or Linux computer, you should have a Unix shell installed.↩︎

title: About this website
text:
This website contains the teaching materials of Jelmer Poelstra (MCIC Wooster, Ohio State University) in the CABANAnet/STC-CGIAR workshop Latin American workshop on high throughput sequencing for plant pathogen identification and analysis.
This workshop was held from Feb 5th to Feb 9th, 2024, in Chachapoyas, Peru.
The source code for this website can be found at https://github.com/jelmerp/cabana-workshop.



 Back to top
